quizz.qcm_question: Q1. Comment pouvez-vous vérifiez la version de git installé?
Q2. Quelle commande permet de créer une connexion entre un déôt local et un dépôt distant ?

Q3. Décrivez ce que font ces commandes sur l'historique de vos commits:

git reset --hard HEAD~5
git merge --squash HEAD@{1}
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: They reset the HEAD to the fifth commit in the repo, then merge to the master branch.
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: The current branch's HEAD is reset back five commits, then prior commits are squashed into a single commit.
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: They delete the last five commits.
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition:
They merge the last five commits into a new branch.

**Explanation:**
reset --hard HEAD~5 resets the current branch to the commit just before the last 5 (see man gitrevisions for details about this notation and other cool alternatives like HEAD@{2 days ago}). As it is a hard reset, it will also overwrite every change in the working tree as well. See man git-reset.
- merge --squash HEAD@{1} HEAD@{1} is where the branch was just before the previous command (again, see man gitrevisions). This command sets the state of the index to be as it would just after a merge from that commit. This whole operation could be a way to take 5 commits from a branch in which you started a new feature and squash them to a single commit, a meaningful one.

quizz.qcm_question: Q4. Your current project has several branches; master, beta, and push-notifications. You've just finished the notification feature in the push-notification branch, and you want to commit it to beta branch. How can you accomplish this?
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: Checkout the push-notifications branch and run git merge beta
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: Checkout the master branch and run git merge beta -> push-notification
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: Delete the push-notification branch and it will be committed to the master branch automatically
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: Checkout the beta branch and run git merge push-notification

quizz.qcm_question:
Q5. Which of the following is 1 you when you use the following command?
add -A
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: All new and updated files are staged
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: Files are staged in alphabetical order.

quizz.qcm_question:
Q6. What will the following command print to the Terminal?
remote -v
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: A list of remote repositories and their URLs
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: The current git version you're running
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: An inline editor for modifying remote repositories
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: The last 5 git versions you've installed

quizz.qcm_question:
Q8. What does the following command do to the git repository?
reset --soft HEAD^
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: It deletes all previous commits and reset the repository history back to its initial state.
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: It resets the working branch to the first commit.
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: It keeps the HEAD at the current commit, but clears all previous commits.
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: It sets HEAD to the previous commit and leaves changes from the undone commit in the stage/index.

quizz.qcm_question: Q9. You find a bug in your project, but can't locate where it was introduced in the commit history. How would you diagnose this problem?
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: Manually backtrack through your commit history.
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: Use git search -diff to compare all commits in your repository history.
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: Run a git rebase to find the buggy commit.
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: Use git bisect to compare the buggy commit to an early commit that works as expected.

quizz.qcm_question:
Q10. Why would the following command be used?
rebase -i HEAD~10
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: To run a comparative search of the last 10 commits for differences
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: To list the last 10 commits and modify them with either the squash or fixup command
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: To delete the last 10 commits and reset the HEAD
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: In order to locally cache the last 10 commits

quizz.qcm_question: Q11. Why would you use a pre-receive hook in your remote repository?
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: You wouldn't, you would use it in the local repository
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: To execute a script when a remote receives a push that is triggered before any refs are updated
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: To fire a script after updates are made to the remote repository
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: To debug all commit tags and release versions

quizz.qcm_question: Q12. What option can you use to apply git configurations across your entire git environment?
Q13. How could you squash multiple commits together without using git merge --squash?
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: You can't. git merge --squash is the only git command for that operation.

quizz.qcm_question: Q14. If you cloned an existing git repository, what would happen?
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: A new copy would overwrite the central repository
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: A copy of the repository would be created on your local machine
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: Nothing, cloning is not a supported git function
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: A copy of the repository would be created on the hosting platform

quizz.qcm_question: Q15. How can you display a list of files added or modified in a specific commit?
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: Find the commit in the remote repository, as that's the only place that kind of information is stored.
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: Use the diff-tree command with the commit hash.
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: Run commit --info with the commit hash.
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: Access the commit stash data with stash.

quizz.qcm_question:
Q16. What files is this .gitignore programmed to leave out?
shell
#.swift
build/
*.txt
*.metadata
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: All files with a .swift, .txt, or metadata file extension, as well as the entire build directory
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: All files in the build directory, as well as files ending with .txt or .metadata
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition:
Only files with .swift and .txt extensions.
A line starting with # serves as a comment. Hence # .swift does not do anything. See man gitignore.

quizz.qcm_question:
Q17. After you make changes to a local repository, you run the following command. What will this do?
commit -a -m "Refactor code base"
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: Nothing, you can't use multiple options in the same command
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: Adds all new files to the staging area
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: Commits all new files with a message
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: Adds all modified files to the staging area, then commits them with a message

quizz.qcm_question:
Q18. After checking your git status you get the following output, which shows the file beta-notes.js in the commit but also unstaged. How can this situation occur?

Change to be committed:
(use 'git reset HEAD ...' to unstage)
modified: beta-notes.js
Changes not staged for commit:
(use 'git add ...' to update what will be committed)
(use 'git checkout --...' to discard changes in working directory)
modified: beta-notes.js
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: There were two copies of beta-notes.js but one was deleted
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: beta-notes.js was staged, then modified afterwards, creating two different versions of the file
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: Two copies of beta-notes.js were created, but only one is being tracked
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: There are two tracked copies of beta-notes.js, but one was removed from the commit

quizz.qcm_question: Q19. Where are files stored before they are committed to the local repository?
Q20. What commands would you use to force an overwrite of your local files with the master branch?
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition:
⠀

git pull -u origin master
git reset --hard master
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition:
⠀

git pull origin master
git reset --hard origin/myCurrentBranch
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition:
⠀

git fetch --all
git reset --hard origin/master

- The command pull is fetch followed by either merge or rebase (in this case, merge). We don't want to merge. Merge would be an action to our **repository**. We just want to overwrite our **local files**.

quizz.qcm_question: Q21. Which statement is 1 when you use the git add -A command?
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: Only new files in the working directory are staged to the index.
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: All new and updated files from the working directory are staged to the index.
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: All files in the working directory are staged to the index in alphabetical order.
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: Only updated files in the working directory are staged to the index.

quizz.qcm_question: Q22. You find that your project has a tag and branch both named push-notifications, which causes confusion when trying to print out given reference. How can you specify which branch you want to look at?
Q23. Your team lead needs a list of all commits that will be moved before you perform a rebase. Which command can you use to access that information?

Q24. What is the operation doing given the Git commands below?

git bisect start
git bisect bad 5d41402abc4b2a76b9719d911017c592
git bisect good 69faab6268350295550de7d587bc323d
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: It runs a merge of a good commit that is discovered using a known bad commit and known good commit
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: It marks a commit for deletion using a known bad commit and known good commit to determine which commit introduced a bug
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: It defines a bad commit and resets the HEAD using a known bad commit and known good commit
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: It performs a binary search using a known bad commit and known good commit to determine which commit introduced a bug

quizz.qcm_question: Q25. In a situation where you have several commits for a single task, what is the most efficient way to restructure your commit history?
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: Cherry pick the related commits to another branch.
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: Delete the task commits and recommit with a new message.
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: Squash the related commits together into a single coherent commit.
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: Stash the related commits under a new hash.

quizz.qcm_question: Q26. Which of the following is 1 of the git push command?
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: By default a push doesn't send tags to the remote repository.
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: Commits can only be tagged when they are created.
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: Tags are pushed to the remote repository with their respective commits.
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition:
Only annotated tags are automatically pushed to the remote repository with a commit.
[Reference](https://git-scm.com/book/en/v2/Git-Basics-Tagging#_sharing_tags)

quizz.qcm_question:
Q27. After pushing commits to the remote repository for the first time using the command below, what shorthand command can you use in future?

git push -u origin master
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: Same as before, git push -u origin master

quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: Assign a shortcut or command using git options file.
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: Create an alias using the git config command.

quizz.qcm_question:
Q29. What is the status of the beta-notes.js file in the following output?
shell
Changes not staged for commit:
(use 'git add ...' to update what will be committed)
(use 'git checkout -- ...' to discard changes in working directory)
modified: beta-notes.js
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: beta-notes.js is untracked and has been modified.
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: beta-notes.js is a tracked file and has been modified, but has not been added to the current commit.
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: beta-notes.js is untracked but has been added to the current commit.
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: beta-notes.js is tracked, and the modified file has been added to the current commit.

rm --cached testfile.js

quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: testfile.js will be removed from the staging area but its changes will still be tracked.

quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: The current copy of testfile.js will be saved in the staging area.

quizz.qcm_question: Q33. After you've successfully merged two branches and committed the changes, what is the next step in keeping your git structure organized?

quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: Use git clear-all to clean up any hanging files.
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: Run git rebase to move the current commit to its original location.

quizz.qcm_question: Q34. While modifying a file, you're unexpectedly assigned an urgent bug fix on another branch. How can you temporarily save your local work without committing?

quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: Run git hold to save a local copy of what you're doing to return to later.
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: Save your work with git local-cache.
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: Use git stash to save your work and come back later and reapply the stashed commit.

4

quizz.qcm_question: Q64. How does Git internally manage branches?

Q66. What is a remote repository?

quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: the lead repository elected by the Git arbitrator found within local repositories of collaborating team members
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: a read-only version of the repository stored on a backup server in case local repositories become lost or corrupted
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: a version of the repository hosted on the internet or network that is pushed to or pulled from by collaborators

quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: Rebase affects only your repository and creates a diff in the master branch.

quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: Rebase moves the HEAD of the remote master branch one commit forward.
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: Rebase deletes all commit history for the new feature branch.

Q75. What conflicts can occur when forcing a push after rebasing?
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: The remote master branch could have existing changes overwritten.
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: The origin URL will be reset to its default value.
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: The current HEAD will be deleted and can't be reinstated.
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: Nothing, it's common practice to force a push after rebasing.

quizz.qcm_question:
Q76. How does this command alter the currently checked-out branch?
reset --soft HEAD^
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: It resets the working branch to the first commit.
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: It sets HEAD to previous commit and leaves changes from the undone commit in the stage/index.
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: It deletes all previous commits and resets the repository history back to its initial state.
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: It keeps the HEAD at the current commit, but clears all previous commits.

quizz.qcm_question: Q77. What is the difference between Git and SVN?
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: Git works only on Linux, while SVN works on all operating systems.
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: SVN works only on Linux, while Git works on all operating systems.
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: SVN is a centralized system, while Git is a distributed system.
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: Git a centralized system, while SVN is a distributed system.

quizz.qcm_question:
Q78. This command is an example of what kind of tag?
tag -a v1.4 -m 'ABCD v1.5'
Q79. What is the difference between a soft reset ( reset --soft) and a hard reset ( reset –hard) ?
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: A soft reset only changes the commit that HEAD points to, while a hard reset resets the index and working tree to match the specified commit, discarding any changes.
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: A soft reset caches the old HEAD pointer, while a hard reset deletes it entirely.
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: A hard reset changes only where the HEAD is pointing, while a soft reset changes the HEAD and index.
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: A hard reset caches the old HEAD pointer, while a soft reset deletes it entirely.

quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: a programmatic design pattern used to manage code between multiple engineering teams

quizz.qcm_question: Q83. What is the difference between using the git stash and git stash pop commands?
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: git stash removes a commit from the repo history, while git stash pop saves changes to multiple branches.
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: git stash saves changes to multiple branches, while git stash pop removes a commit from the repo history.
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: git stash removes the most recent commit, while git stash pop saves current changes.
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: git stash creates a stash entry, while git stash pop places the saved state onto the working directory.

quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: shell script pointers and keychain credentials
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: updates to branch tips and other references in the local repository

quizz.qcm_question: Q89. You have just completed rebasing your master branch and need to manually update the remote master, even though there is a merge conflict. How can you accomplish this?
Q90. What is the difference between fetch and pull
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: fetch creates a new branch off the master branch, while pull creates a new branch off the local repository's master branch.
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: pull downloads new data from a remote repository without integrating it into local files, while fetch updates the current HEAD branch with the latest changes from the remote server.
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: fetch updates remote tracking branches with changes from a remote repository, while pull updates remote tracking branches with changes from a remote repository and merges them into their corresponding local branches.
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: fetch downloads and merges data from the local repository, while pull informs your colleagues you are about to make changes to the master branch.

quizz.qcm_question: Q91. What command displays the difference between the working tree and the stage/index area, as well as files not tracked by Git?

Q92. Your current repository has three branches: master, beta, and push-notifications. You have just finished the notification feature and commit the changes to the push-notification branch, and you want to include them in the beta branch. How can you accomplish this?
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: Check out the beta branch and run git merge push-notifications.
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: Check out the push-notifications branch and run git merge beta.
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: Check out the master branch and run git merge beta -> push-notifications.
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: Delete the push-notifications branch; it will be committed to the master branch automatically.

quizz.qcm_question: Q93. You would like to restore some previously stashed work to a new branch. How can you do that?
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: Add the stashed commits to the current commit, then create a new branch.

quizz.qcm_question: Q94. What is the difference between git branch -d and git branch -D?
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: -D deletes the local branch, while -d deletes the branch regardless of push and merge status.
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: -d deletes the current commit head, while -D deletes the entire branch.
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: -d deletes the local branch, while -D deletes the local branch regardless of push and merge status.
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: -D deletes the current commit head, while -d deletes the entire branch.

quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: By default, a push doesn't send tags to the remote repository.
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: Only annotated tags are automatically pushed to the remote repository with a commit.
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: Tags are pushed to the remote repository with their respective commits.
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition:
Commits can be tagged only when they are created.

quizz.qcm_question: Q97. How would you delete a remote branch in your repository?

Q99. How does the -p option change the behavior of the add command
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: It causes tracked files in the parent directory to be included in the staged files.
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: It allows developers to interactively choose which changes to tracked files are staged and outputs the differences for review.
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: It automatically pushes changes to the corresponding branch on the remote repository.
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition:
It allows developers to interactively choose which files are committed and outputs the differences for review.
[reference here](https://git-scm.com/docs/git-add#Documentation/git-add.txt--p)

quizz.qcm_question: Q100. After checking out a specific commit, you receive a warning message indicating You are in 'detached HEAD' state. What is Git warning you of?
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: You are not working on the most recent commit of a branch.
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: A teammate has flagged the code with an issue.
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: The commit does not have a parent.
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition:
The branch has not been pushed to the remote repository.
[reference here](https://www.git-tower.com/learn/git/faq/detached-head-when-checkout-commit)

quizz.qcm_question: Q101. After accidentally deleting a branch in your local repository, how can you recover it?
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: Find the hash of the branch with the log command, then execute checkout -b .
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: Find the hash of the branch with the reflog command, then execute checkout -b .

quizz.qcm_question: Q102. How would you display a histogram showing inserts, deletion, and modifications per file for a specific commit along with its general commit information?
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: Query the remote repository with the commit hash.

quizz.qcm_question: Q103. What features do repository managers such as GitHub provide beyond Git?
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: Repository managers are proprietary versions of Git that do not include enhanced features.
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: Repository managers provide an enhanced command-line tool that is used to manage multiple local repositories.
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: Repository managers provide an online service for hosting Git repositories that include collaboration features such as pull requests, issue tracking, and peer reviews.
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition:
Repository managers distribute repositories across multiple locations on a user's workstation, providing redundant storage that allows for quick backup and recovery.
[reference](https://www.theserverside.com/video/Git-vs-GitHub-What-is-the-difference-between-them)

quizz.qcm_question: Q104. What command finds the HEAD of the current branch?
Q105. When Git Workflows contain a long-running branch, what purpose does the long-running branch serve?
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: Long-running branches store unstable code until it os peer reviewed for integration into a feature branch.
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: Long-running branches correspond to agile sprints and are used to store related to features developed in the sprint.
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: Long-running branches contain code related to experimental feature development that is merged into short-lived branches such as master.
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: Long-running branches correspond to different stages of development and are always open for topic/feature branches to be pulled into.

quizz.qcm_question: Q106. What command takes changes from the master branch on the remote repository origin and merges then to the local checked-out branch?

Q107. While pushing changes to a remote repository, you receive the following message. How do you resolve this issue?

error: failed to push some refs to 'https://github.com/myrepo/simple.git'
hint: Updates were rejected because the remote contains work that you do not hint: not have locally.
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: Use the --atomic option with the push command.
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: Execute a pull, then resolve any merge conflicts and execute another push.
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: Execute a fetch, then execute another push.
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: Use the --force option with the push command.

quizz.qcm_question: Q108. What does the -p option add to the output of the log command?
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: It adds patch output that shows the differences introduced in each commit.
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: It adds patch output that shows a summary listing modified files.
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: It adds padding to the output and displays a histogram showing the number of lines changed in each commit.
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: It adds the full commit message and notes associated with each commit.

quizz.qcm_question: Q109. What is the staging area or index?
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: an area that stores commits prior to them being pushed to the remote repository
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: an area containing stash entries that can applied to the working files
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: an area where changes from a branch in the remote repository are stored before they are applied to a local branch
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: an area that stores information about changes that will be included in the next commit

quizz.qcm_question: Q110. What command would you use to stage changes to the index strictly for properties files in the current directory?
Q111. What are untracked files?
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: files in the local repository that have not been merged into the master branch
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: staged files that Git does not know about because the have not been committed
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: files in the working directory that Git does not know about because the have not been staged or committed
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: files in the remote repository that Git does not know about because they have not been tagged

quizz.qcm_question: Q112. What command takes changes from the master branch on the remote repository origin and merges them to the local checked-out branch?
Q113. What type of Git hook could be used to validate that a commit message contains a ticket number?
Q114. What is the difference between git stash pop and git stash apply?
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: git stash pop pushes the topmost commit to the current branch, while git stash apply caches the last commit in the current branch.
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: git stash pop applies the topmost entry in the stash to the working files and removes it from the stash, while git stash apply applies the topmost entry in the stash to the working files but leaves it in the stash.
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: git stash pop merges the topmost commit to the current branch, while git stash apply merges the last commit in the current branch.
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: git stash pop applies the topmost entry in the stash to the working files but leaves it in the stash, while git stash apply applies the topmost entry in the stash to the working files and removes it from the stash.

quizz.qcm_question: Q115. After making some major changes to your code, you are a little nervous about committing. What command would you use to review the commit prior to making it?
Q116. What statement best describes Git's concept of HEAD?
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: a pointer to the most recently changed file in the stage/index
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: a pointer to the master branch
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: a pointer to the most recent commit in the currently checked-out branch
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: a pointer to where the repository is stored in memory

quizz.qcm_question: Q117. After staging changes to several files, you realize the changes to the config.properties file are incorrect, and need to be removed from the stage and working directory. What command can you use to remove the staged changes to the file?

Q118. After a recent release with a stack trace, an issue is create that indicates the problem is with a newly added configuration property named MaxConnections. What command can find all commits that add or remove the string MaxConnections?

Q119. Your company has moved its remote repository to GitHub at this location: https://github.com/yourcompany/core-api.git. What command updates the remote repository, named origin, to point to the new remote repository at this location?
Q120. When is the cherry-pick command used?
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: - when a commit from one branch needs to be copied into another branch
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: - when the HEAD needs to be reset to a specific commit
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: - when a specific commit needs to be pulled down from the remote repository
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: - when a hook script needs to be invoked

quizz.qcm_question: Q121. How would you describe a forked repository?
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: - a deleted or archived copy of a repository
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: - a beta release branch of a repository
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: - a future branch of a repository

quizz.qcm_question: Q122. How can you exclude untracked files within the working directory from a Git repository?
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: - You cannot exclude the files from the repository.
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: - Add a pattern matching the files to the .gitignore file.
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition:
- Add the files to the omitted branch
[reference](https://git-scm.com/docs/gitignore)

quizz.qcm_question: Q123. What command creates a near-exact copy of the entire repository from a server?
Q124. What would happen if you ran the reset testfile.js command?
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: testfile.js would be reverted to a blank file.
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: testfile.js would be reset to its first saved state.
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: testfile.js would be reverted to its last saved copy.
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: testfile.js would be removed from the stage/index area, if present.

quizz.qcm_question: Q125. What situation can occur when attempting to combine branches containing changes to the same piece of code?
Q126. What command creates a near-exact copy of the entire repository from a server?
Q127. When Git workflows contain a topic branch, what purpose does the topic branch serve?
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: Topic branches store unstable code until it is peer reviewed for integration into another feature branch. <url>
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: Topic branches correspond to different stages of development and are always open for long-running branches to be pulled into. <url>
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: Topic branches are used in waterfall development methodologies to track the state of the code during the various stages of waterfall. <url>
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: Topic branches are short-lived branches used to store work related to a particular feature. <url>

quizz.qcm_question: Q128. What practice can help reduce the chances of encountering a merge conflict?
quizz.qcm_r1_proposition: Provide detailed commit messages that describe the changes being introduced by the commit. <url>
quizz.qcm_r2_proposition: make large commits that introduce multiple features. <url>
quizz.qcm_r3_proposition: Keep local repository branches in sync with upstream branches in the remote repository by committing,pushing and pulling frequently. <url>
quizz.qcm_r4_proposition: Avoid frequent interaction with the remote repository to reduce the probability of pulling conflicts. <url>
